description.narrative: HIPS will anchor the new Five Year strategic plan (2018-2022) around two broad pillars: research action and policy action. The overall objectives are: Strategic objective 1: To develop programs and conduct research in the priority thematic areas of peace, justice and good governance.Strategic objective 2: To foster inclusive public dialogues that will influence policy, increase transparency and accountability and inform HIPS research agenda.Strategic objective 3: To ensure sufficient staff in both numbers and capacity to deliver organizational objectivesStrategic objective 4: To fully computerize the core and support functions of HIPS. ActivitiesStrategic objective 5: To secure predictable, diversified and adequate funding streams that enable HIPS to operate effectively. To raise US$300,000 to buy HIPS’s own premises by 2022.

Den föreslagna insatsen har till syfte att bidra till den pågående stabiliserings- och statsbyggnadsprocessen i Somalia.
The Heritage Institute of Policy Studies (HIPS) är Somalias främsta fristående och oberoende tankesmedja som inrättades 2013, och förser beslutsfattare med fullödiga analyser och praktiska rekommendationer baserade på oberoende evidensbaserad forskning. Syftet är att bidra med analyser, identifiera vägval och lämna förslag på möjliga lösningar på de politiska och sociala utmaningar som Somalia står inför. HIPS syfte är att få forskning och idédebatt att leda fram till konkret politisk förändring som bidrar till Somalias återuppbyggnad. Under de fem åren sedan starten har HIPS, med sina analyser, bidragit till att förändra och förnya det politiska debattklimatet i Somalia. HIPS spelar en allt mer central roll i den somaliska samhällsdebatten. Utöva att bedriva forskning, arrangerar HIPS regelbundet seminarier och rundabordssamtal. HIPS ordnar även egna konferenser, publicerar böcker, rapporter och policypapper. HIPS ledning medverkar regelbundet i samtal, debattprogram i välrespekterade Tv-kanaler och radio såsom BBC och VOA. Som Somalias främsta tankesmedja har HIPS främjat kulturen för evidensbaserad policyframställning i Somalia och blivit ett lokalt respekterat och internationellt erkänt varumärke. Som ett centrum för spetskompetens inom forskning i Somalia, kretsar HIPS: s arbete kring två breda pelare - research action and policy action. För att säkerställa att HIPS produktion når sina olika målgrupper använder HIPS somaliska och engelska språket för alla sina forskningspublikationer och policyrekommendationer samt i sitt påverkansarbete. HIPS strävar efter att vara öppen plattform för idéutbyte och kunskapsspridning.
Inom forskningsområdet producerar HIPS forskningsrapporter som syftar till strategiska viktiga frågor inom freds-, stats- och institutionsbyggandet. HIPS:s studier om AMISOM, högre utbildning, federalism, konstitutionen, flyktingar, landfrågor, torka och påverkan från yttre aktörer har förmedlats på bred front bland beslutsfattare och har därmed haft mätbar effekt på tagna beslut i landet. Vidare har HIPS:s policypapper fokuserat på dagsaktuella och relevanta problemställningar, såsom federalism, konfliktlösningsmekanismer samt återvändande diaspora, och försett politiska beslutsfattare med analyser och praktiska rekommendationer. Exempelvis har det utvecklats policypapper som fokuserar på konflikten mellan federala regeringen och delstaterna Kismaayo och Gaalkacyo och hur den kan lösas. Ett annat policypapper handlar om kvinnors politiska och medborgerliga engagemang i samhället. De policypapperen har utvecklats och förmedlats i perioder då dessa frågor var aktuella och behovet av att belysa och analysera de på ett opartiskt sätt var nödvändigt.
På policyområdet erbjuder HIPS flaggskeppsprogram, Forum for Ideas, en interaktiv plattform för Somalias beslutsfattare, praktiker, företagsledare, civilsamhällets aktörer, akademiker och samhällsaktivister. Rundbordsdiskussioner organiserade i Mogadishu och i de regionala huvudstäderna och det årliga forumet för idéer (AFI) som hålls i Djibouti lockar medborgare från hela Somalia inklusive den självutropade, men internationellt icke-erkända Somaliland samt somalier från Afrikas horn och många i diasporan.

The proposed intervention aims to contribute to the ongoing stabilization and state-building process in Somalia.
The Heritage Institute of Policy Studies (HIPS), an independent Somalia's first think tank, established in 2013, provides policy makers with succinct analyses and practical recommendations based on independent evidence-based research. In the five years since its inception, the Heritage Institute for Policy Studies (HIPS) has contributed to the transformation of the policy environment in Somalia. As Somalia’s first think tank, HIPS has promoted culture of evidence-based policymaking across Somalia and has become a locally respected and internationally recognized brand. As a center of excellence in research in Somalia, HIPS’ work revolves around two broad pillars – research action and policy action. To ensure the output reaches all its various audiences, HIPS uses Somali and English for all its research activities, policy action and advocacy.
In the research sphere, HIPS produces original research reports on strategically important issues for Somalia’s peace building, state building and institution building agenda. HIPS studies on AMISOM, higher education, federalism, the constitution, refugees, land issues, drought and the influences of external actors were well circulated among policy circles and had measurable impact on policy making in the country. Similarly, HIPS policy briefs have focused on the pertinent thorny issues of the day and provided policy makers with succinct analyses and practical recommendations. Briefings on how to end the Kismaayo and Gaalkacyo conflicts and our studies on diaspora return, citizens’ priorities and perceptions, the political and civic engagement of Somali women, federalism and governance were all released periods where these issues where deliberated in a bipartisan fashion and fact-based analysis and forward-looking insight were most needed.
On the policy front, HIPS’s flagship program, Forum for Ideas, offers an interactive platform for Somalia’s policymakers, practitioners, business leaders, civil society, academia and activists. Both the roundtable discussions organized in Mogadishu and in the regional capitals and the Annual Forum for Ideas (AFI) held in Djibouti attract citizens from across Somalia, including self-declared state of Somaliland but internationally considered to be part of Somalia, as well Somalis from the Horn of Africa and many in the diaspora.

description.narrative: Some 2019 key achievements include: • In 2019, the Heritage Institute for Policy Studies (HIPS) publications and research work have addressed wide range of issues spanning from: appraisal of government’s first two years, 2019 year in review, impediments to good governance, power sharing in federal Somalia, bicameral parliament, mitigating of the Galmudug crisis and human capital development. The Galmudug study titled, The Galmudug Crisis: A Blueprint for Sustainable Settlement and the recommendations it put forth has contributed to putting the peacebuilding and governance needs of this troublesome state on the national leaders' and international community's radar. HIPS election model options paper titled Somalia: In Search of a Workable 2020 Electoral Model was one of the early if not the first publication that discussed one person one vote was not forthcoming in Somalia and it presented four options in July 2019. The model adopted a year and half a year later is a watered-down version of one of the options presented in the options paper. • A major research priority for 2019 was a human capital development mechanism project (HCDM) that a HIPS-led consortium undertook. The findings of HIPS human capital development studies convinced the federal ministry of planning to designate 'human capital development' as a national priority and included that in the National Development Plan 2020 to 2024 (NDP-9).See Chapter 8: Social Development Pillar (PILLAR 4) of the NDP-9.• To complement the research activities as stated in the strategic plan, the institute engaged in a broad range of activities as part of its policy action. There are three components of policy action: (i) Annual Forum for Ideas (AFI); (ii) forums in the regions each year to promote democratic deliberation after or before each study are published and (iii) engagement with national decision makers, international actors directly and citizens through forums the media. These forums have provided a platform that brings on board a diverse range of actors and stakeholders who come together to discuss priority issues for Somalia and are informed by HIPS research that is informing and influencing public policy making in Somalia. • Moreover, due Sida´s multi-year support, HIPS has managed to secure additional core funding support from the Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) to advance one of the institute’s research agenda and policy action with a focus on good governance. In summary, since its establishment, HIPS has continued to contribute to the transformation of the policy environment and has promoted a culture of evidence-based policy discussions in Somalia. Moreover, HIPS has raised more funds mainly due both growth in program funded activities and improved fundraising efforts by HIPS in 2019. HIPS has now managed to diversify sources of funding and not only rely on Sida support. This diversification of funds remains an a key target for HIPS in phase 2 of Sida´s core support. In 2020, Sida has entered into agreement on delegated cooperation with Royal Danish Embassy, RDE-Nairobi (so called Nordic + arrangement) regarding core support to HIPS where RDE has committed DKK 9 million in three years (2020-2022). Sida is currently conducting a major amendment to the agreement with HIPS as a result of the agreement between Sida and RDE. However, since Sida’s current support is up to 2021, Sida is extending its core support for an additional one year in order to harmonize with RDE support period to 2022. The proposed additional support for 2022 is SEK 3.5 million.
